title: R42562
content: The Moving to Work (MTW) program was established by Congress in 1996 to allow HUD and local PHAs to test new policies for housing assistance programs. Over 30 PHAs are currently participating in MTW, managing billions in funding to support low-income families. The future of MTW is uncertain despite its goals of increasing cost-effectiveness, promoting self-sufficiency, and expanding housing choices. The Moving to Work (MTW) program, established in 1996, receives $2.7 billion for Section 8 Housing Choice Vouchers and $1.1 billion for public housing, supporting 13% of vouchers and 11% of public housing units. The future of MTW is uncertain as current agreements are set to expire in 2018, with calls for changes emerging. Critics argue that MTW agencies have too much flexibility with unknown impacts on low-income families, while supporters believe the program allows for unique and cost-effective ways to serve more families. The MTW demonstration program's flexibility has led to conflicting views on its success, with calls to end, change, or expand the program. Evaluating the program's effectiveness is challenging due to its design and implementation. Some argue for restructuring the program to better serve its original purpose as a testing ground for innovations in assisted housing provision. The MTW demonstration program has sparked debates about its future, with some advocating for restructuring to align with its original purpose of testing housing innovations. Others believe MTW agencies have shown success operating outside traditional regulations, suggesting a modified program for the future of assisted housing. Despite controversy, MTW policies have influenced reforms in mainstream housing programs, with Congress considering these insights for future federal housing assistance reforms. The Moving to Work (MTW) demonstration program, authorized in 1996, allows PHAs to test new approaches for providing housing assistance to low-income families. The program aims to reduce costs, promote self-sufficiency, and increase housing options. Up to 30 PHAs can participate in the program through a competitive selection process, with detailed evaluations conducted for up to 15 agencies to identify successful models for replication. The Moving to Work (MTW) demonstration program allows PHAs to develop and test their own policies for providing housing assistance to low-income families. This includes combining funding streams, waiving statutory requirements, and designing a "reasonable" rent policy.
